articles.headline: Credit Score, by Multiple Choice
articles.snippet: Where credit scores are rare, banks are using a psychometric test developed at Harvard to help lend to small-business owners.
articles.abstract: Where credit scores are rare, banks are using a psychometric test developed at Harvard to help lend to small-business owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: No credit? No problem — just take a test.

articles.headline: Russian Tycoon Is Free, but His Money Is Still Tied Up
articles.snippet: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky was worth an estimated $15 billion when he went to prison 10 years ago. Now, he can only guess at how much of it is left.
articles.abstract: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky was worth an estimated $15 billion when he went to prison 10 years ago. Now, he can only guess at how much of it is left.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Before he went to prison 10 years ago, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky was Russia’s richest man, worth maybe $15 billion. Set free this month, he could only guess at his vastly depleted, but still formidable, wealth.

articles.headline: Clothing Brands Sidestep Blame for Safety Lapses
articles.snippet: Months after the collapse of the Rana Plaza complex in Bangladesh exposed abuses in the garment industry, there is no consensus on what responsibility global chains should bear for reform and compensation.
articles.abstract: Months after the collapse of the Rana Plaza complex in Bangladesh exposed abuses in the garment industry, there is no consensus on what responsibility global chains should bear for reform and compensation.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARETS DEL VALLÈS, Spain — From a sleek gray distribution center near Barcelona, the global fashion brand Mango ships 60 million garments in a year. Automated conveyor belts whir through the building like subway lines, sorting and organizing blouses, sweaters and other items to be shipped around the world. Human hands barely touch the clothes.

articles.headline: Social Media as a Megaphone to Pressure the Food Industry
articles.snippet: Parents and advocacy groups are tapping the power of the web to force food companies to reconsider what they put in their products.
articles.abstract: Parents and advocacy groups are tapping the power of the web to force food companies to reconsider what they put in their products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Renee Shutters has long worried that food dyes — used in candy like blue M&M’s — were hurting her son, Trenton.

articles.headline: American-Style Start-Ups Take Root in India
articles.snippet: In a nation with a reputation as a tough place to do business, American tech entrepreneurs are importing the Silicon Valley mind-set.
articles.abstract: In a nation with a reputation as a tough place to do business, American tech entrepreneurs are importing the Silicon Valley mind-set.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — India has built a reputation as a notoriously tough place to do business, one that has stymied even giants like Walmart. And unlike Silicon Valley, where a decent idea can attract funding, investors in India are much more reluctant to risk their money on start-ups.

articles.headline: The Worst, the Best, and Some Odd Couples
articles.snippet: Andrew Ross Sorkin draws up the annual “Closing Dinner” guest list, and toasts and roasts figures from the realm of finance and business.
articles.abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin draws up the annual “Closing Dinner” guest list, and toasts and roasts figures from the realm of finance and business.

articles.headline: Senate Discord Drains Power of Finance Chief
articles.snippet: Amid a drift from bipartisanship, the once-esteemed chairmanship of the Senate Finance Committee has declined in stature, and the next leader is likely to have diminished clout.
articles.abstract: Amid a drift from bipartisanship, the once-esteemed chairmanship of the Senate Finance Committee has declined in stature, and the next leader is likely to have diminished clout.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After the Reagan landslide of 1980 swept Bob Dole into the chairmanship of the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Dole was not sure how to break the news to Russell B. Long, the Louisiana Democrat who had presided over the panel with unquestioned authority for 15 years.

articles.headline: Global Optimism for 2014, With an Eye on Dormant Risks
articles.snippet: Although buoyed by a resurgence of stock markets in Japan and Europe, many investors were still wary, given the swiftness of the rebounds.
articles.abstract: Although buoyed by a resurgence of stock markets in Japan and Europe, many investors were still wary, given the swiftness of the rebounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: If Shinzo Abe and Mario Draghi were being compensated by investment banks rather than taxpayers, they would both be looking forward to some pretty hefty year-end bonuses.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing, Neil Gough and David Jolly
